title: ProRep
motivation: In light of the recent Vancouver municipal election and BC referendum on electoral reform, I decdied to ramp up my civil engagement. I was triggered by an acquaintance hitting me with the 'Why do you vote? It doesn't change a thing anyway!' at a seemingly docile dinner party. I made this tool to help my friends decide in a more hands-on-way whether they support a system based on proportional representation.
fun: Ease-of-use of the create-react-app node package and Webpack, a new tool I hadn't used before. Also, inline SVG's and the fact that they can be manipulated through CSS.
pain: Writing the React component for a custom range slider (with two sliders in this case)  took days, and a surprising amount of custom code for a seemingly simple web component.

title: BikeCouch
motivation: A hiatus-summer, a very appropriately tailored Google News Feed and the desire to learn something new. I had tried Apache Cordova on a student project before, and was left with rather mixed feelings. On top of that, I wanted to get some experience with (quasi) native mobile development. The Flutter SDK was a natural pick - as the newest kid on the block - and was a pleasure to work in from the get-go and its more wide-spread adoption is something to look forward to!

technologies.content: A mix of the following tech:

fun: All the struggle to create a minimalistic, but working UI is taken away by Flutter by their great 'Evertyhing is a Widget' approach. Scaffolding is a question of seconda, letting you focus on the important pieces and enabling you to whip up an app in mere days.
pain: At the time of development, the documentation and community support of Flutter was not great.

title: Lexical Schema Matcher
motivation: This is the coding part of my Hnrs. Computer Science & Physics degree, completed during my last year in college. Open Data is something I didn't know existed, and while I was working on this project it grew to something that I hope I supported by writing about it.
fun: Molding something academic into a real-world application (to the best of my ability!).
pain: Web scraping is a tedious and very feeble endeavour...

title: MonsterServer
motivation: A recent passion for the decade-old role playing game Dungeons & Dragons sparked this one. This simple server is used to server monster information to another app that I am currently building with a friend.
pain: Gists are unnecessarily hard to embed in React.js.
